rounds.response:
Let me make sure I understand the numbers first.

Current inventory  
Qty | Value each | Total value  
18 Wheat  5  →  90  
16 Wood   12 → 192  
18 Sheep  15 → 270  
9  Brick  21 → 189  
20 Ore    35 → 700  
Total portfolio: 1 441

Incoming offer  
Opponent offers: 1 Sheep for 1 Brick from me.

- I give 1 Brick → lose 21 value  
- I get 1 Sheep → gain 15 value  
Net change: –6 expected value.

That’s unfavorable, so I should reject it.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
My current resource values seem low to me, so I’d like to upgrade.

After re-evaluating the board, Brick (21) and Ore (35) look scarce and powerful, while I have plenty of Sheep (15).  
Converting lower-value Sheep into Brick would boost my total value, but my last 3-for-5 offer was refused, so I have to sweeten the pot.

I’m now prepared to give up a bit more Sheep to secure the Brick I want.

[Offer: 5 Sheep -> 7 Brick]

rounds.response:
So far both players have stonewalled each other.

The facts I can extract:
- In every turn so far, when a sheep / brick trade was discussed, Player 0 asked for 1 – 7 brick while offering only 1 – 5 sheep.  
- My own valuations:
  – 1 Brick = 21  
  – 1 Sheep = 15  
  – So every rejected offer over-values Brick (from my side) – no wonder Player 0 rejected them.

My current inventory is still
Wheat-18 @5  
Wood-16 @12  
Sheep-18 @15  
Brick-9  @21  
Ore-20  @35

Goal: increase the **sum value of my holdings**.  Brick is the scarcest good and I already have little (9 only), while I have a surplus of every other resource.  Therefore I would still like **more Brick**, but only if I don’t give away more value than I receive.

Proposed new tactic:  
– Offer to give Player 0 **one of my two highest-quantity surplus goods** at a ratio that still gives Player 0 better than 1:1 Brick:other ratio.  
– I have 18 Wheat (5) and 20 Ore (35) – Wheat is extremely low in value and high in quantity, so it’s the perfect resource to unload.  I’ll try to dangle Wheat instead of Sheep and see if Player 0 reacts.

New offer:
[Offer: 10 Wheat -> 5 Brick]

rounds.response:
As Player 1, I see that Player 0 has rejected my previous offer (10 Wheat for 5 Brick). They seem unwilling to part with Brick at any of the rates I’ve floated so far. Since my highest goal is to raise the total value of my resources, the best thing to do is convince Player 0 to give me Brick for goods they actually want, at a ratio they’ll accept.

I need to adjust the per-unit value gap: my last offer valued Brick at 21 points each (5 for 21 → 105 value), substantially below its face value to me. Player 0 probably has Brick valued higher than that.

Let me offer a pair of high-value cards (Ore) to entice them while still keeping my net value positive. Specifically, 2 Ore (35 each = 70 points to me; likely just as high for P0) for 3 Brick (21 each = 63 points to me). Net change: −70 + 63 = −7 in direct swap terms, but it fills my inventory with an item that is currently scarce. Given the past rejections, this appears to be the cheapest feasible way to acquire more Brick.

[Offer: 2 Ore -> 3 Brick]
